awd_titl_txt: UNS:   Collaborative Research:   Effects of Nano-Bio Interactions on Nanoparticle Fate and Transport in Porous Media
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite dramatic increases in the production and use of engineered nanomaterials in industrial and consumer products, very little is known about the fate and transport of nanoparticles following their release into the environment. The overall goal of this project is to better understand the interactions between engineered nanoparticles and microbial communities, and to use this information to improve predictions of nanoparticle accumulation and mobility in soils, groundwater, and water treatment systems. To broaden the educational outreach and practical implications of this work, the project includes research experiences for undergraduate students and the development of interactive, multi-media instructional tools that will be incorporated into educational and training programs run by the Center for Engineering Education and Outreach and Center for Science, Technology, Engineering and Math Diversity. 

Research conducted over the past ten years has greatly improved our knowledge of nanoparticle aggregation and mobility over a range of environmentally-relevant conditions, and has informed the development of mathematical models capable of describing nanoparticle transport and retention in membranes, filter beds and aquifer materials. At the same time, numerous studies have explored the impacts of nanoparticles on cellular systems, aquatic invertebrates, fish, and microorganisms. The overall goal of this research project is to combine these two lines of research to investigate the role of nano-bio interactions on nanoparticle fate and transport in porous media. The research project is coupling nanoparticle characterization and biotic experiments with dynamic transport studies to quantify the effects of nano-bio interactions on the mobility and fate of representative engineered nanomaterials (iron oxide and magnesium oxide) in aquifer materials and natural soils. Research activities are being structured around three tasks, (1) determination of nanoparticle deposition and release as a function of surface coating aging, biopolymers, and solution composition using a quartz crystal microbalance, (2) assessment of the effects of biopolymers on nanomaterial mobility and retention in abiotic columns, and (3) measurement of nanoparticle transport, deposition, and aging in aerobic and anaerobic bio-active soil columns. Novel aspects of the research include the direct coupling of microbial-particle interactions with transport, assessment of bio-related deposition, direct observation of nanoparticle behavior using flow-through scanning electron microscopy and cryo-transmission electron microscopy techniques. Results obtained from this work are being used to explore the role of microbial communities in the aging nanoparticle surface coatings, and the impacts of filter ripening and site blocking on nanoparticle attachment processes and mobility in the environment. To extend the impact of this work beyond traditional academic boundaries, research outcomes are being incorporated into model-based tutorials, short instructional videos, and illustrative case studies and modeling tools that will be disseminated through collaborations and participation in initiatives with the Center for Science Technology, Engineering and Math Diversity, the Bridge to Engineering Success at Tufts, and the Center for Engineering Education and Outreach at Brown.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Research conducted over the past decade has greatly improved our understanding of nanoparticle behavior in the environment and has informed the development of mathematical models capable of describing nanoparticle transport and retention in membranes, filter beds, and aquifer materials.  At the same time, numerous studies have explored the impacts of nanoparticles on cellular systems, aquatic invertebrates, fish, and microorganisms.  The overall goal of this collaborative research project was to combine these two lines of research to investigate the role of nano-bio interactions on nanoparticle fate and transport in soils and aquifer materials. The research integrated nanoparticle characterization and biotic experiments with dynamic transport studies to quantify the effects of nano-bio interactions on the mobility and fate of representative engineered nanomaterials (iron oxide and silver) in representative aquifer materials and natural soils.  A combination of batch, column and mathematical modeling studies were undertaken to assess the effects of a representative biopolymer, rhamnolipid, on nanomaterial mobility and retention in sterile and soil columns. 

The results of column transport studies conducted with iron oxide nanoparticles demonstrated that the presence of rhamnolipid increases the mobility of iron nanoparticles in soils and aquifer materials.  The effect was attributed to the ability of rhamnolipid, even at relatively low concentrations, to stabilize the nanoparticles and block nanoparticle attachment sites.  To further interpret the experimental results and provide predictive capabilities, a multi-constituent nanoparticle transport model was modified to incorporate nanoparticle straining and filter ripening processes. The refined model provided more accurate simulation of iron nanoparticle transport and retention in porous media and can be used to predict the transport behavior of nanoparticles in the presence of other biopolymers.   

For silver nanoparticles, the results of batch and column studies showed that the presence of rhamnolipid at low concentrations (< 5 mg/L) enhanced particle aggregation and reduced the rate of dissolution to form silver ions.  However, at higher concentrations (10 and 50 mg/L), the presence of rhamnolipid increased particle stability (no aggregation was observed) and further reduced the dissolution of silver nanoparticles.  In water-saturated soil columns, silver nanoparticles were completely retained within the soil at pH 4 and aerobic conditions (dissolved oxygen = 9 mg/L), and only silver ions were detected in the column effluent. In contrast, when rhamnolipid was present, the amount of silver ions detected in the column effluent was greatly reduced.  The observation attributed to coating of the silver nanoparticle surfaces surface by rhamnolipid, which resulted in less surface area available for dissolution.

In biologically active experiments, the addition of a surface coating such as oleic acid to nanoparticles protects the surface microbially-mediated reactions but did not eliminate the susceptibility of iron nanoparticles to iron reduction. Additionally, iron nanoparticles that were coated with oleic acid were impacted by exposure to sulfide and subject to biodegradation by aerobic bacteria.  In column transport experiments conducted in the presence of a biofilm- and biosurfactant-producing bacteria (P. fluorescens), the presence of the biofilm completely inhibited transport of iron oxide nanoparticles through columns packed with water-saturated quartz sands irrespective of transport fluid composition, ionic strength, or flow rate.  These findings demonstrate that biofilms and biopolymers can dramatically alter nanoparticle transport in soils by altering the surface reactivity of nanoparticles, and either increasing or decreasing nanoparticle mobility.  Specifically, biofilms can reduce nanoparticle transport, whereas biopolymers in solution greatly increase nanoparticle stability and transport.  

Theses

  • Duhl, T. Microbially-mediated transformations of chlorinated solvents and engineered nanomaterials in the subsurface: Implications for bioremediation, natural attenuation, fate and transport, Ph.D. dissertation., Tufts University, 2020.
  • Liao, S. Effects of Co-Constituents on the Fate and Transport of Emerging Contaminants in Porous Media. Ph.D. dissertation, Brown University, 2021.

Journal Publications

  • Liao, S., D. Pinchbeck, N.L. C?piro, J.F. Fortner, L.M. Abriola, K.D. Pennell. 2021. Effects of rhamnolipid biosurfactant on the dissolution and transport of silver nanoparticles in porous media. Environ. Sci.: Nano, 9:2492-2506.
  • Liao, S., A. Ghosh, M.D. Becker, L.M. Abriola, N.L C?piro, J.D. Fortner, K.D. Pennell. 2021. Effect of rhamnolipid biosurfactant on transport and retention of iron oxide nanoparticles in water-saturated quartz sand. Environ. Sci. Nano, 8: 311-327.
  • Kim, C., K.D. Pennell, J.D. Fortner. 2020. Delineating the relationship between nanoparticle attachment efficiency and fluid flow velocity. Environ. Sci. Technol., 54: 13992-13999.

Presentations

  • Pennell, K.D. 2019. Influence of polymers and surfactants on nanoparticle mobility in porous media, SPWLA, Porous Media: Structure, Flow, and Dynamics Workshop, Boston, MA (Invited).
  • Mohammadnejad, H., B. Marion, K.D. Pennell, L.M Abriola. 2019. Development and validation of a new transport model for co injection of nonionic polymers and nanoparticles in porous media, AEHS Annual International Conference on Soils, Sediments, Water, and Energy, Amherst, MA.
  • Capiro, N.L., T. R. Duhl, S. Liao, A. Ghosh, J. D. Fortner and K. D. Pennell. Effect of Aerobic Biosurfactant Producing Soil Bacteria on the Transport and Retention of Iron Oxide Nanoparticles in Water-Saturated Quartz Sand. American Geophysical Union Fall 2021 Meeting. (Invited).

 

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Kurt Pennell
